stories.text:
I am having my first mentee (an intern), and I am still an entry-level software engineer (1 year working experience). Any tips on how to mentor? Things to look out for?

A few things that I currently struggle with:

- difficult to gauge how much they know, and how slow/fast I should in explaining stuff

- distraction (I am excited to mentor, hence my brain keep coming back to that (providing resources, reviewing their work, etc.) while I am supposed to do my work)

- how detailed/nitpicking should I be in reviewing, how to explain the right concept at the right time

Thanks!
stories.title: Ask HN: Any Tips on Mentoring an Intern?
psi-notify – alert when resources on your machine are becoming oversaturated

stories.text:
I came up with a ridiculous method myself. It works, but I wonder if other people came up with other things.

What I can't do:

* Earplugs

If I do that then the earplugs will get into my ear whenever I sleep on my side. This aggravates the tinnitus sound.

What I can do:

* Earplugs + Airpods Max with ANC off

The earplugs will not get into my ear because the shelf surrounding my ear from the Airpods Max protect it. ANC needs to be off because when I side sleep, the microphone that is meant for ANC goes in some feedback loop and then I hear all kinds of beeps. If I lay on my back I can put ANC on.

That's my method, I'm looking to improve it to either block more sound. I'd also be happy with to block as much sound as I do now while lying more comfortable. Having an Airpods Max on is slightly less comfortable than without.

With that said, I'd argue that this method is also really helpful for people without tinnitus since it blocks more sound than just earplugs alone. The passive noise cancellation from having a shelf around your ear from a headphone blocks a lot of low frequency sounds it seems.

In any case, how do you do it?
stories.title: Ask HN: People with tinnitus how do you block sound when you sleep?
